They don't build Burke destroyers in Norfolk.    They're build in Bath Maine or Pascagoula, Mississippi.    I used to install the VLS missile launchers in the 1990s at Ingalls, Pascagoula, MS.   Also, carriers are *only* built in Newport News, VA.   In Norfolk, those ships are already commissioned.

Is it possible Trump awarded the contracts to the best build companies not best lobbied.
Have you considered this?

I ask cause I know nothing about this subject.

It's those shipyards (Newport News, Bath Iron Works, and Ingalls) are the only ones equipped to build those classes of ships, not to mention having space to do so.    Additionally, Newport News is one of two shipyards equipped/certified to install nuclear reactors, a necessity for carriers.

These were not in the water they were up on the dry dock with some pretty massive pieces of steel still being welded on to it, they were not completely painted nor did they have commissioned names or numbers on them. And Aircraft carriers were also being built along side them.  Our guide said they were destroyers however he never said what class or type they were.

Yeah, I've been on both types of ships and it's two different worlds.  The carrier is massive and like a city with plenty of strangers on-board.  A destroyer is quite small comparatively, but everyone knows everyone else making it more like a family.   Very different...
Be way better to have 5 little ships than 1 big one. Much harder for the chunks to sink with out most advanced tech.

Have your grandson keep away from that high intensity electronic stuff of he will get cancer.
I didn't use to think that. but a relative of mine was really into HAM radio and he got brain cancer, as did three other HAM operators he knew.

I have held an Advanced Class Amateur Radio (HAM) License for over 35 years, Most "Hams" have been on the air over 50 + years. If there's a connection to RF Exposure and Brain Cancer to Ham Operators, It's because of POOR Engineering Practices and Lack of understanding and compliance with the FCC's "Bulletin 65" Regarding RF Exposure, Frequencies and Wattage and Safety. I am Also Retired USN, I'm sure I've been hit with RF more than once while Underway. Face it, our Bodies are being bombarded by  low power, Ultra-High Frequency RF 24/7/365 and with Cell Phones and towers it only getting worse.

These guys were old school. Built their own radios and amps and things. Maybe things have improved in the last 30 years. It was just spooky when I learned that four guys who knew each other only over the radio should get brain cancer. Apparently the only thing they had in common was HAM radio.

Yeah, we all get it every day, but I believe most of it is too weak or diffuse to do any harm, There's a radar sitting out in the country not too far from here. Air traffic control. If you drive by with your radio on a static setting between AM stations you can hear the radar when it scans over you. Makes a "whump" sound on the radio.

There's too many unanswered questions to make the assumption it was Ham Radio.
IE: AGE, Area of Residence, City/Rural, Employment, Medical History and Family History, Exposure Risks, Etc.
Four Sailors on a Tin Can I served on Became Diabetic within a six month Period, 2 guys got  Stomach Cancer, bad chow? I'm thinking too much Coffee, but again I don't know. I think the ARRL  and FCC would be pushing for more Awareness if there was a major connection between Brain Cancer and RF radiation from a Ham Radio Transmitter.

"Radar works by sending a series of electro-magnetic signals or “pings” at the speed of light, which bounce off an object or threat and send back return-signal information identifying the shape, size, speed or distance of the object encountered. Analyzing the speed, frequency, range and variation of the return signals enable radar operators to develop a rendering or precise “picture” in a way of what a specific threat may be. "

ECM works by receiving the incoming radar signal and sending back misinformation as to the shape, size, speed or distance of the object encountered. Analyzing the speed, frequency, range and variation of the return signals causes the sending ship's weapons to miss their intended targets.
